There is an infinite base

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Matroid α} [self : Matroid.InfiniteRk M], ∃ B, M.Base B ∧ Set.Infinite B
name: Matroid.InfiniteRk.exists_infinite_base
docString: There is an infinite base

The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

type: {p | p.Prime}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ p.Prime
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ Nat.Prime p
statement: theorem Nat.exists_infinite_primes : ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ p.Prime := by sorry
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString:
Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.
description: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.
concise-description: For every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p > n`.

For every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p > n`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ Nat.Prime p
statement: theorem Nat.exists_infinite_primes : ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ p.Prime := by sorry
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString:
Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.
description: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.
concise-description: For every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p > n`.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

type: ¬BddAbove {p | p.Prime}
name: Nat.not_bddAbove_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

This theorem states that for any natural number `b` that is greater than or equal to 1, the set of natural numbers `n` that are Fermat pseudoprimes to the base `b` is infinite. In other words, there are infinitely many natural numbers `n` that satisfy Fermat's Little Theorem for a specific `b`, but are not actually prime numbers.

type: ∀ {b : ℕ}, 1 ≤ b → {n | n.FermatPsp b}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_pseudoprimes
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `b` that is greater than or equal to 1, the set of natural numbers `n` that are Fermat pseudoprimes to the base `b` is infinite. In other words, there are infinitely many natural numbers `n` that satisfy Fermat's Little Theorem for a specific `b`, but are not actually prime numbers.

For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

type: ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → {p | Nat.Prime p ∧ p ≡ 1 [MOD k]}.Infinite
statement: theorem Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one : ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → {p | p.Prime ∧ k.ModEq p 1}.Infinite := by sorry
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one
docString: For any positive `k : ℕ` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`.
description: This theorem asserts that, for any positive natural number `k`, there are infinitely many prime numbers `p` that satisfy the congruence `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`. In other words, when these prime numbers `p` are divided by `k`, the remainder is always 1. This remains true regardless of the value of `k`, as long as `k` is not zero.
concise-description: For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

type: Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0}
name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, s.Infinite → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ k.ModEq m n
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString: For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

This theorem states that for all positive base numbers greater than or equal to one, there exist infinite Fermat pseudoprimes to that base. More specifically, for any given numbers `b` and `m`, where `b` is greater than or equal to 1, there exists a Fermat pseudoprime `n` to the base `b` such that `n` is greater than or equal to `m`. The structure of this theorem is analogous to the theorem `Nat.exists_infinite_primes`, which asserts the existence of infinite prime numbers.

type: ∀ {b : ℕ}, 1 ≤ b → ∀ (m : ℕ), ∃ n, n.FermatPsp b ∧ m ≤ n
name: Nat.exists_infinite_pseudoprimes
docString: This theorem states that for all positive base numbers greater than or equal to one, there exist infinite Fermat pseudoprimes to that base. More specifically, for any given numbers `b` and `m`, where `b` is greater than or equal to 1, there exists a Fermat pseudoprime `n` to the base `b` such that `n` is greater than or equal to `m`. The structure of this theorem is analogous to the theorem `Nat.exists_infinite_primes`, which asserts the existence of infinite prime numbers.

For every positive integer `b` and `m`, there exists an infinite sequence of Fermat pseudoprimes `n` to the base `b` such that `n` is greater than or equal to `m`.

type: ∀ {b : ℕ}, 1 ≤ b → ∀ (m : ℕ), ∃ n, n.FermatPsp b ∧ m ≤ n
statement: theorem Nat.exists_infinite_pseudoprimes : ∀ {b : ℕ}, 1 ≤ b → ∀ (m : ℕ), ∃ n, n.FermatPsp b ∧ m ≤ n := by sorry
name: Nat.exists_infinite_pseudoprimes
docString:
For all positive bases, there exist infinite **Fermat pseudoprimes** to that base.
Given in this form: for all numbers `b ≥ 1` and `m`, there exists a pseudoprime `n` to base `b` such
that `m ≤ n`. This form is similar to `Nat.exists_infinite_primes`.
description: This theorem states that for all positive base numbers greater than or equal to one, there exist infinite Fermat pseudoprimes to that base. More specifically, for any given numbers `b` and `m`, where `b` is greater than or equal to 1, there exists a Fermat pseudoprime `n` to the base `b` such that `n` is greater than or equal to `m`. The structure of this theorem is analogous to the theorem `Nat.exists_infinite_primes`, which asserts the existence of infinite prime numbers.
concise-description: For every positive integer `b` and `m`, there exists an infinite sequence of Fermat pseudoprimes `n` to the base `b` such that `n` is greater than or equal to `m`.

The type of prime numbers

type: Type
name: Nat.Primes
docString: The type of prime numbers

For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

type: ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → {p | p.Prime ∧ k.ModEq p 1}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one
docString: For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

This theorem asserts that, for any positive natural number `k`, there are infinitely many prime numbers `p` that satisfy the congruence `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`. In other words, when these prime numbers `p` are divided by `k`, the remainder is always 1. This remains true regardless of the value of `k`, as long as `k` is not zero.

type: ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → {p | p.Prime ∧ k.ModEq p 1}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one
docString: This theorem asserts that, for any positive natural number `k`, there are infinitely many prime numbers `p` that satisfy the congruence `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`. In other words, when these prime numbers `p` are divided by `k`, the remainder is always 1. This remains true regardless of the value of `k`, as long as `k` is not zero.

A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

Positive integers biject with multisets of primes.

type: ℕ+ ≃ PrimeMultiset
name: PNat.factorMultisetEquiv
docString: Positive integers biject with multisets of primes.

There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

type: ∀ {α : Type u} {a : Set α}, Set.Finite a → Set.Finite {b | b ⊆ a}
name: Set.Finite.finite_subsets
docString: There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set
